entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Web Smart Card API
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Web+Smart+Card+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Web Smart Card API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251017" rel="nofollow">Fri, 17 Oct 2025 20:51:36 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2 (thanks for the very well-written explainer, btw).</pre><pre>
On 10/6/25 2:19 p.m., Alex Russell wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM1
On Thursday, October 2, 2025 at 12:57:05 PM UTC-7 Reilly Grant wrote:
LGTM as an IWA OWNER (3x LGTM from Blink API OWNERS are still required according to the IWA-specific API launch process <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/isolated-web-apps/">https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/isolated-web-apps/</a>>).
Similar to Unrestricted WebUSB, this API is granting access to devices which we've made an explicit decision not to give to normal web sites. The additional integrity provided by IWAs allows us to make a meaningful decision that if access is granted to an app then the app's behavior is well-known and cannot be compromised by common attack vectors.
This API exists to support specific, mainly enterprise-focused, use cases. On the broader web device-based authentication solutions such as WebAuthn are more appropriate. Reilly Grant | Software Engineer |<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3f4d5a56531111117f5c574d5052564a5211504d58">[email protected]</a> |Google Chrome <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.google.com/chrome">https://www.google.com/chrome</a>>
On Thu, Oct 2, 2025 at 6:39 AM Luke Klimek <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="fe84998cd0d0d0be9d968c9193978b93d0918c99">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Contact emails
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="98e2ffeab6b6b6d8fbf0eaf7f5f1edf5b6f7eaff">[email protected]</a>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="d0b4b1beb4a2b1fefefe90b7bfbfb7bcb5feb3bfbd">[email protected]</a>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/README.md</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/README.md</a>>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card">https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card">https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card</a>>
Summary
Enables smart card (PC/SC) applications to move to the Web platform. It gives them access to the PC/SC implementation (and card reader drivers) available in the host OS.
Administrators can control the availability of this API either:
* Globally—using the DefaultSmartCardConnectSetting policy. * Per-application—using the SmartCardConnectAllowedForUrls and SmartCardConnectBlockedForUrls policies.
Blink component
Blink>SmartCard
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ESmartCard%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ESmartCard%22</a>>
Web Feature ID
None
TAG review
This is an IWA-only API, and TAG has made it clear recently that they don't want to review IWA-related stuff. Relevant statement:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/842#issuecomment-2917031448">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/842#issuecomment-2917031448</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/842#issuecomment-2917031448">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/842#issuecomment-2917031448</a>>
TAG review status
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Other browsers may choose to implement this API, that is however dependent on adoption of the Isolated Web Apps as a whole.
Gecko: No signal
WebKit: No signal
Web developers: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/issues/43">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/issues/43</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/issues/43">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/issues/43</a>>)
Other signals:
Security
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card?tab=readme-ov-file#security-and-privacy-considerations">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card?tab=readme-ov-file#security-and-privacy-considerations</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card?tab=readme-ov-file#security-and-privacy-considerations">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card?tab=readme-ov-file#security-and-privacy-considerations</a>>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card/#security-privacy">https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card/#security-privacy</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card/#security-privacy">https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card/#security-privacy</a>>
This is a highly security-sensitive API. This is why it is currently being guarded behind:
1.
Isolated Web App installation (and also declaration of the `smart-card` permission policy in the manifest
2.
Fine-grained user-facing permission mechanism that gives the end user control over the most privacy-sensitive moments (connection to a smart card reader).
For more context on the permissions design and how it interacts with Chrome UI and enterprise policy see go/web-smart-card-api-permissions <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://goto.google.com/web-smart-card-api-permissions">http://goto.google.com/web-smart-card-api-permissions</a>>(sorry, Googlers-only).
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None.
Debuggability
The code using this API can be debugged using the standard tools. Potential future improvement would be a new CDP domain to allow mocking system PC/SC to not rely on actual hardware.
More design explorations at go/web-smart-card-api-cdp <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://goto.google.com/web-smart-card-api-cdp">http://goto.google.com/web-smart-card-api-cdp</a>>, sorry, Googlers-only. Complexity of this endeavour however makes us defer this at least until cross-platform launch. This is a part of a broader effort to add WPTs to this feature: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/40275258">https://crbug.com/40275258</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/40275258">https://crbug.com/40275258</a>>
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No. Underlying implementation highly depends on the system native PC/SC stack. ChromeOS is the first platform implemented. Also, IWAs themselves are not currently launched anywhere else.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
No. WPT does not support IWA test environments. Once that support is available, we can investigate adding IWA-focused WPT tests. Also, implementation also is highly complex, as the API depends on communication with the native system PC/SC and actual hardware. Future WPT implementation, tentatively planned for the cross-platform launch is tracked here: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/40275258">https://crbug.com/40275258</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/40275258">https://crbug.com/40275258</a>>
DevTrial instructions
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/HOWTO.md">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/HOWTO.md</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/HOWTO.md">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/HOWTO.md</a>>
Flag name on about://flags
enable-smart-card-web-api
Finch feature name
SmartCard
Rollout plan
Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome?
True
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1386175">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1386175</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1386175">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1386175</a>>
Launch bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4234437">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4234437</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4234437">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4234437</a>>
Measurement
UseCounters:
1. SmartCardEstablishContext: Entry point to the API overall. 2. SmartCardConnect: Entry point to actually using API for communication with smart card readers.
Availability expectation
API is available only in Chromium browsers for the foreseeable future—no other browser engine has yet displayed interest in implementing Isolated Web Apps, which are a prerequisite to this API. Initially API will be available on ChromeOS only, with intent to implement it elsewhere later (as Isolated Web Apps are launched on other platforms).
Adoption expectation
Expected to be used initially by a small number of developers inside Isolated Web Apps.
Adoption plan
Working directly with developers that are planning to rely on the API.
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function?
Yes. This API depends on the system-specific PC/SC implementation, as it is essentially a proxy to it. For the initial launch on ChromeOS, this extension is the sample provider that should be installed in Chrome for the API to function: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/chromeos_smart_card_connector">https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/chromeos_smart_card_connector</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/chromeos_smart_card_connector">https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/chromeos_smart_card_connector</a>>On the other platforms, we will probably add new dependencies (PCSC on Windows and PC/SC lite elsewhere) to the Chromium project itself.
Sample links
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/web-smartcard-demo">https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/web-smartcard-demo</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/web-smartcard-demo">https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/web-smartcard-demo</a>>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop
143
DevTrial on desktop
141
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype%5C%3A+Algorithm+Updates+in+WebCrypto%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Algorithm Updates in WebCrypto</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251017" rel="nofollow">Fri, 17 Oct 2025 21:11:04 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="761e1558585836151e04191b1f031b58190411">[email protected]</a> </pre><pre>
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/webcrypto-modern-algos">https://wicg.github.io/webcrypto-modern-algos</a>
Summary Add post-quantum cryptography and a common symmetric AEAD to the set of cryptographic algorithms available in the Web Cryptography API. This will enable developers to have access browser-provided implementations of common quantum-resistant cryptographic algorithms standardized by NIST. * ML-KEM - 768, 1024 * ML-DSA - 44, 65, 87 * ChaCha20-Poly1305
Blink component Blink>WebCrypto
Web Feature ID web-cryptography
Motivation Web Crypto exposes various low-level primitives, however none of the public/private key cryptography is currently quantum-resistant Adding quantum-resistant cryptography as a primitive to the existing WebCrypto APIs allows Javascript cryptography libraries to automatically use browser-provided cryptography (which may be more securely implemented and/or backed by a FIPS-validated underlying library), rather than compiling OpenSSL to WebAssembly or reimplementing algorithms in pure Javascript (or simply not being PQC). Many Javascript cryptography libraries fall back to WebCrypto when it is available—these libraries will now be able to use BoringSSL-provided implementations instead of pure Javascript implementations.

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Scoped+Custom+Element+Registry%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Scoped Custom Element Registry</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251017" rel="nofollow">Fri, 17 Oct 2025 21:18:54 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2
On 10/14/25 1:53 p.m., Rick Byers wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Oh sounds good, thanks Jayson.</pre><pre>
Rick
</pre><tt>On Tue, Oct 14, 2025 at 1:35 PM 'Jayson Chen' via blink-dev </tt><tt><<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0d6f616463662069687b4d6e657f626064786023627f6a">[email protected]</a>> wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
I believe we are going right to status=stable when we ship the feature. Currently with ScopedCustomElementRegistry feature flag on, it is passing all WPTs for custom elements, including the ones created specifically for scoped registry work. It's being tested under this virtual test suite: third_party/blink/web_tests/virtual/scoped-custom-element-registry/
Debuggability wise, I agree that it's something valuable and worth exploring given that we can have different constructors under the same element name now.

<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/runtime_enabled_features.json5;l=4307?q=ScopedCustomElementRegistry%20file:%5C.json5&ss=chromium">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/runtime_enabled_features.json5;l=4307?q=ScopedCustomElementRegistry%20file:%5C.json5&ss=chromium</a>> the feature is still in status=test mode and so the WPTs

*Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="cca1adbfa3a2e2e2e28caba3a3aba0a9e2afa3a1">[email protected]</a>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="066c677f7569282828466b6f657469756960722865696b">[email protected]</a>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="bed2dbd1909090fed3d7ddccd1cdd1d8ca90ddd1d3">[email protected]</a>

<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/webcomponents/blob/gh-pages/proposals/Scoped-Custom-Element-Registries.md">https://github.com/WICG/webcomponents/blob/gh-pages/proposals/Scoped-Custom-Element-Registries.md</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10854">https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10854</a>
*Specification*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/custom-elements.html#customelementregistry">https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/custom-elements.html#customelementregistry</a>
*Summary* This feature allows for multiple custom element definitions for a single tag name to exist within a page to prevent custom element name conflicts when a web app uses libraries from multiple sources. This is achieved by allowing user code to create multiple custom element registries and associate them with tree scopes and elements that function as scoping object for custom element creation/definition/upgrade.

*TAG review status* Issues addressed

/Web developers/: Positive Scoped custom element registry has been a long-awaited feature from the Web Components Community Group, and the current polyfill that didn't solve the entire problem has 24k+ downloads per week.

None

I played with this a little and I guess I can always just rely on commands like $0.constructor to find the relevant source. But Firefox has a UI badge and hover action for this:

Perhaps the scoped custom element registry makes a UI feature like this go from nice-to-have to essential? @Danil Somsikov for his thoughts since he reviewed and approved the Debuggability bit for this feature.

entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Requests two changes for the existing Permission Element (PEPC) Origin Trial
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Requests+two+changes+for+the+existing+Permission+Element+%5C%28PEPC%5C%29+Origin+Trial%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Requests two changes for the existing Permission Element (PEPC) Origin Trial</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251017" rel="nofollow">Fri, 17 Oct 2025 21:45:30 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> On 9/26/25 6:23 a.m., Mike Taylor wrote:
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>A note on timing: the OT expires in M140, which means that users who </tt><tt>upgrade to M141 (scheduled to go out next week) will no longer have </tt><tt>access to the feature. November 11th is the day after the hard-coded </tt><tt>expiration date of Nov 10th for all users (i.e., folks who haven't </tt><tt>upgraded past 140). That means your partners will need to deploy the </tt><tt>newly minted extension token before 141 goes out to avoid any </tt><tt>disruption. So if you click on that button I can approve and maybe </tt><tt>they can hit that deadline. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre></blockquote><tt>A small correction here: the feature will continue to work for any </tt><tt>version where the feature exists (so, M141+) until the hard-coded Nov </tt><tt>11th expiration date. So less stress for partners, but they will want to </tt><tt>deploy the updated token before then. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> On 9/26/25 6:11 a.m., 'Minh Le' via blink-dev wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Hello blink-dev,
</pre><tt>Our team requests two changes for the existing Permission Element </tt><tt>(PEPC) Origin Trial. <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5125006551416832">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5125006551416832</a>> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
1.
A timeline extensionfor three milestones, to M143.
2.
An increase in the page load limitfrom 0.5% to ~5% of Chrome page loads.
</pre><tt>The current Origin Trial for PEPC is set to expire with M140 (Nov </tt><tt>11th), while we are targeting the launch of the standardized </tt><tt><geolocation> API </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/PEPC/blob/main/geolocation_explainer.md">https://github.com/WICG/PEPC/blob/main/geolocation_explainer.md</a>>inM143 </tt><tt>and preparing a new OT for a <usermedia> API </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/PEPC/blob/main/usermedia_element.md">https://github.com/WICG/PEPC/blob/main/usermedia_element.md</a>>. The </tt><tt>extension is needed to prevent a disruption for our partners, and the </tt><tt>page load increase is critical for new experimentation and for </tt><tt>ensuring a smooth, validated path to a full launch. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Rationale for Extension & Page Load Increase
The PEPC API is already providing significant, measurable user benefits
1.
Unlocking Value and De-risking the Launch:
*
Preventing Partner Disruption:For example, in a high-traffic web service, users who specifically clicked 'Use precise location' previously encountered barriers to changing their settings if they had blocked location permissions. PEPC resolved this, leading to approximately +17pp and +36pp increases in successfully adjusting settings on Desktop and Mobile, respectively.” Extending the trial ensures that partners like Zoom, Cisco, Zaplmoves, and OLX BR,Meet, Searchand others do not lose this functionality until we roll this change out. (see some use cases here <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/rethinking-web-permissions">https://developer.chrome.com/blog/rethinking-web-permissions</a>>)
*
Validating at Scale:An increased page load limit allows our high-traffic partners to scale their successful implementations beyond the current OT cap. This delivers the feature's proven benefits to a wider audience sooner and, critically, allows us to validate that the positive results from a small experiment carry over at a larger scale, mitigating risks before the full M143 launch.
2.
Enabling New, High-Impact Experimentation: We need to increase the page load limit to validate PEPC's integration with the upcoming Approximate Location <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/approximate-geolocation">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/approximate-geolocation</a>>feature.
*
PEPC provides a natural, user-initiated entry point for managing location granularity (e.g., changing from approximate to precise and vice versa).
*
To get this right, we need to test several UI variations (different button treatments and prompts) for this new user flow.
*
A higher page load limit is necessary to gather statistically significant data across these experimental arms, ensuring we can differentiate user behavior and build the best possible experience before launch.
3.
New Experimentation Plan: Based on valuable feedback from other browser vendors, we are splitting the generic <permission> element into capability-specific elements. This OT extension provides a bridge to that future:
*
Geolocation: The learnings from the current OT (including the Approximate Location experiments) will directly inform the launch of the new <geolocation> element, targeted for M143.
*
User Media (Camera/Mic): We will create a new, separate OT for <usermedia> to continue collaborative development on its API shape after the current OT expires.
</pre><tt>This plan ensures continuity for our partners while allowing us to </tt><tt>ship the most stable, consensus-driven solution. We appreciate your </tt><tt>consideration and welcome any questions. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Best regards,
Minh on behalf of the Chrome PEPC Team

Thanks so much for making this easier to understand. Helps a lot, and as a result, I now understand that the design has a problem:
JSON allows a single string value as a valid payload; e.g. JSON.parse(`"foo"`). This seems to be a problem for the design, which relies on authors sending objects instead of strings as a reliable discriminator. How can you validate that this isn't going to create issues in the wild?
</pre><tt>The explainer suggests conditioning RP behavior on the type, I think </tt><tt>this works right? the IDP has to continue to know that tokens are </tt><tt>always objects (just optionally encoded as JSON serialized strings), </tt><tt>never just bare strings. But that's not a new requirement. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>Now of course there's the RP/IDP compatibility problem that comes from </tt><tt>any new RP-exposed FedCM feature an IDP can opt-into and I assume </tt><tt>that would be on IDPs to manage like they manage any other change in </tt><tt>their protocol with their RPs. Eg. Google Sign-in would presumably </tt><tt>update their SDK to support both token formats but wait for some </tt><tt>period before actually sending the new token formats to all RPs </tt><tt>(probably trialing only with RPs they know have updated). Whether it </tt><tt>actually is worth the effort for any IDP to migrate is unclear to me. </tt><tt>But if an IDP new to FedCM wanted this then I don't see a problem, right? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Best,
Alex

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Requests+two+changes+for+the+existing+Permission+Element+%5C%28PEPC%5C%29+Origin+Trial%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Requests two changes for the existing Permission Element (PEPC) Origin Trial</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251018" rel="nofollow">Sat, 18 Oct 2025 00:04:56 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> Thanks - LGTM to extend to M143.
But we'll need 3 owners for the higher %. LGTM1 for that.</pre><pre>
On 9/26/25 9:31 a.m., Minh Le wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Hi Mike, </pre><tt>thank you so much for your quick reply and instructions, I hit the </tt><tt>button :) </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> And I will let the partners know as soon as we get the new token. Best, Minh
</pre><tt>On Fri, Sep 26, 2025 at 3:24 PM Mike Taylor <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="cea3a7a5abbaafe0e0e08eada6bca1a3a7bba3e0a1bca9">[email protected]</a>> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Hi there,
I see a lot of good reasons to extend here. But could you please go to your chromestatus entry and in the Origin Trial section click "Request another trial extension" button, and fill it out with the details in this message?
A note on timing: the OT expires in M140, which means that users who upgrade to M141 (scheduled to go out next week) will no longer have access to the feature. November 11th is the day after the hard-coded expiration date of Nov 10th for all users (i.e., folks who haven't upgraded past 140). That means your partners will need to deploy the newly minted extension token before 141 goes out to avoid any disruption. So if you click on that button I can approve and maybe they can hit that deadline.
thanks, Mike
On 9/26/25 6:11 a.m., 'Minh Le' via blink-dev wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Hello blink-dev,
Our team requests two changes for the existing Permission Element (PEPC) Origin Trial. <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5125006551416832">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5125006551416832</a>>
1.
A timeline extensionfor three milestones, to M143.
2.
An increase in the page load limitfrom 0.5% to ~5% of Chrome page loads.
The current Origin Trial for PEPC is set to expire with M140 (Nov 11th), while we are targeting the launch of the standardized <geolocation> API <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/PEPC/blob/main/geolocation_explainer.md">https://github.com/WICG/PEPC/blob/main/geolocation_explainer.md</a>>inM143 and preparing a new OT for a <usermedia> API <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/PEPC/blob/main/usermedia_element.md">https://github.com/WICG/PEPC/blob/main/usermedia_element.md</a>>. The extension is needed to prevent a disruption for our partners, and the page load increase is critical for new experimentation and for ensuring a smooth, validated path to a full launch.
Rationale for Extension & Page Load Increase
The PEPC API is already providing significant, measurable user benefits
1.
Unlocking Value and De-risking the Launch:
*
Preventing Partner Disruption:For example, in a high-traffic web service, users who specifically clicked 'Use precise location' previously encountered barriers to changing their settings if they had blocked location permissions. PEPC resolved this, leading to approximately +17pp and +36pp increases in successfully adjusting settings on Desktop and Mobile, respectively.” Extending the trial ensures that partners like Zoom, Cisco, Zaplmoves, and OLX BR,Meet, Searchand others do not lose this functionality until we roll this change out. (see some use cases here <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/rethinking-web-permissions">https://developer.chrome.com/blog/rethinking-web-permissions</a>>)
*
Validating at Scale:An increased page load limit allows our high-traffic partners to scale their successful implementations beyond the current OT cap. This delivers the feature's proven benefits to a wider audience sooner and, critically, allows us to validate that the positive results from a small experiment carry over at a larger scale, mitigating risks before the full M143 launch.
2.
Enabling New, High-Impact Experimentation: We need to increase the page load limit to validate PEPC's integration with the upcoming Approximate Location
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/approximate-geolocation">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/approximate-geolocation</a>>feature.
*
PEPC provides a natural, user-initiated entry point for managing location granularity (e.g., changing from approximate to precise and vice versa).
*
To get this right, we need to test several UI variations (different button treatments and prompts) for this new user flow.
*
A higher page load limit is necessary to gather statistically significant data across these experimental arms, ensuring we can differentiate user behavior and build the best possible experience before launch.
3.
New Experimentation Plan: Based on valuable feedback from other browser vendors, we are splitting the generic <permission> element into capability-specific elements. This OT extension provides a bridge to that future:
*
Geolocation: The learnings from the current OT (including the Approximate Location experiments) will directly inform the launch of the new <geolocation> element, targeted for M143.
*
User Media (Camera/Mic): We will create a new, separate OT for <usermedia> to continue collaborative development on its API shape after the current OT expires.
This plan ensures continuity for our partners while allowing us to ship the most stable, consensus-driven solution. We appreciate your consideration and welcome any questions.
Best regards,
Minh on behalf of the Chrome PEPC Team

It also defines some new ways of customising form controls, covering common use cases that were previously only possible by implementing custom controls from scratch, which was a lot of work, hard to get right, and often broke either accessibility or platform conventions.

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Ready+for+Developer+Testing%5C%3A+Performance+%5C%2B+Event+Timing%5C%3A+InteractionCount%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Ready for Developer Testing: Performance + Event Timing: InteractionCount</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251018" rel="nofollow">Sat, 18 Oct 2025 06:49:58 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="f598989adbdbdbb5929a9a929990db969a98">[email protected]</a> </pre><pre>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount</a>
Design docs No information provided <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#sec-increasing-interaction-count">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#sec-increasing-interaction-count</a>
Summary The Event Timing API is part of the Performance Timeline and is used to measure the performance of user interactions. Certain Events will have an interactionId value assigned to them, and this is useful for grouping related interactions based on common physical user inputs or gestures. This feature adds a very trivial performance.interactionCount, which is just the total number of interactions that have occured on the page. In particular, this feature is useful for computing the Interaction to Next Paint (INP) metric value, which requires knowing the total number of interactions in order to compute a high percentile score (p98 for pages with greater than 50 total interactions). This feature has been specced for a long while, was prototypes in Chromium a long time ago but never shipped, is part of Interop 2025, and is already available in other browsers. (Note: there is already a more powerful performance.eventCounts map for specific events, but it is not possible to accurately map event cunts to interaction counts.)
Blink component Blink>PerformanceAPIs
Web Feature ID event-timing
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility Other browser venders have already shipped this feature as part of the Interop 2025 effort for CWV INP. The main interop risk is that there are existing polyfills for interactionCount in Chromium for INP calculation. However, popular polyfills (such as web-vitals.js) have long been tested to feature detect, given the long experimental web platform implementation in chromium.
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/xvv6sxJZc4U/m/JzSSCoxPAgAJ?e=48417069">https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/xvv6sxJZc4U/m/JzSSCoxPAgAJ?e=48417069</a>)
WebKit: In development (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=297361">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=297361</a>)
Web developers: Strongly positive No specific link, but this feature is related to the very popular INP metric definition (and obviates the need for an imperfect polyfill for counting interactions).
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? n/a
Debuggability DevTools has existing support for Interactions (real time performance monitor and tracing). Visualizing total interactionCount is not needed, but can be easily found (via literally counting the list of interactions, or just console logs).
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/event-timing/">https://wpt.fyi/results/event-timing/</a> (several tests, look for interaction-count-*)
Flag name on about://flags No information provided
Finch feature name EventTimingInteractionCount
Requires code in //chrome? False
Availability expectation Feature is available on Web Platform Baseline within 12 months of launch in Chrome (as part of Interop 2025 for INP)
Adoption expectation Polyfill already widely adopted (for INP calculation), and feature detection already used.
Estimated milestones

DevTrial on Android 111
Shipping on WebView 143

Already specced in Event Timing API.

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Restricting spelling and grammar highlights
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Restricting spelling and grammar highlights
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Restricting+spelling+and+grammar+highlights%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Restricting spelling and grammar highlights</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Ari+Chivukula%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Ari Chivukula</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251018" rel="nofollow">Sat, 18 Oct 2025 08:04:43 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="d3b2a1bab0fdfdfd93b0bba1bcbebaa6befdbca1b4">[email protected]</a>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="2d4c0303036d4a42424a4148034e4240">[email protected]</a>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="e4898d8f819085cacacaa4878c968b898d9189ca8b9683">[email protected]</a>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4428256a6a6a04272c362b292d31296a2b3623">[email protected]</a> Explainer/Specification</pre><pre>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://explainers-by-googlers.github.io/user-dictionary-leaks/">https://explainers-by-googlers.github.io/user-dictionary-leaks/</a>
Summary
This experiment would change when spelling and grammar hints are applied to text fields to reduce the of websites ability to extract information about the user’s dictionary, specifically:
-
Hints would not be applied to a text field that has not had user interaction (an autofocus
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Reference/Global_attributes/autofocus">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Reference/Global_attributes/autofocus</a>> is insufficient, there must be a click or key press of some kind relative to that field). -
Hints would only be applied once per user interaction (the text cannot be changed programmatically and have hints applied without a click or key press of some kind relative to that field).
Blink component
Blink>Editing>Spellcheck <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield0:%22Blink%3EEditing%3ESpellcheck%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield0:%22Blink%3EEditing%3ESpellcheck%22</a>>
TAG review
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1148">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1148</a>
Motivation
The user’s dictionary may contain sensitive information, for example some operating systems import the contents of the user’s address book to assist with the spelling of names/addresses. Although direct indicators of the ::spelling-error and ::grammar-error cannot be extracted, it’s possible to extract indirect information from browsers without rate limits on the application of these hints. In Chrome and Firefox, it’s possible to have an autofocused <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Reference/Global_attributes/autofocus">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Reference/Global_attributes/autofocus</a>> text area cycle programmatically through a series of misspelled words, and for the site to monitor indicators of rendering performance to notice when hints are applied. This allows sites (or their third-party embeds) to detect which words are or aren’t in the user’s dictionary, which could leak sensitive information stored there (for example, their contacts' names). Safari already has rate limits in place which only check for and apply hints once per user interaction with the text field (e.g., a key input or click).
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Safari is already in full compliance with these changes, while Firefox and Chrome are only in partial compliance with the first one (they do count autofocused fields, but don’t apply new hints to fields that aren’t in active focus).
Gecko: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1294">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1294</a>
WebKit: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/546">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/546</a>
Debuggability
This isn’t exposed to DevTools.
Measurement
UMA will be added to the SpellChecker <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/editing/spellcheck/spell_checker.h">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/editing/spellcheck/spell_checker.h</a>> class that notes when hints are registered to the document so that browsers in and out of the experiment can be compared.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests?
No, this isn’t observable outside browsertests.
Flag name on about://flags
N/A
Finch feature name
RestrictSpellingAndGrammarHighlights
Rollout plan
1% experiment on stable to see if this causes any drop in key metrics.
Requires code in //chrome?
No
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/415712674">https://crbug.com/415712674</a>
Estimated milestones
143
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5080415048171520">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5080415048171520</a>

To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGpy5DJnHAOx7Khuqgu-xLgmu3R4UYeqfrkqVasuQx4A0JK_vg%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGpy5DJnHAOx7Khuqgu-xLgmu3R4UYeqfrkqVasuQx4A0JK_vg%40mail.gmail.com</a>. </pre>

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+IDNA+ContextJ+rules%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: IDNA ContextJ rules</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251018" rel="nofollow">Sat, 18 Oct 2025 12:06:58 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM3
On 9/30/25 12:57 a.m., Philip Jägenstedt wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>Great, I have updated the rollout plan in the chromestatus entry to </tt><tt>"Will ship enabled for all users" </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>On Mon, Sep 29, 2025 at 11:39 PM Daniel Clark <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="492d28276767670924202a3b263a262f3d672a2624">[email protected]</a>> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
That sounds reasonable to me.
*From:*Philip Jägenstedt <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="f6909999d8d8d8b6959e84999b9f839bd8998491">[email protected]</a>> *Sent:* Monday, September 29, 2025 12:07 PM *To:* Daniel Clark <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3054515e1e1e1e705d5953425f435f56441e535f5d">[email protected]</a>> *Cc:* blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1e7c72777075337a7b685e7d766c7173776b7330716c79">[email protected]</a>>; <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="bfccd3d6d8d7919191ffdcd7cdd0d2d6cad291d0cdd8">[email protected]</a> <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="93e0fffaf4fbe7ffeabdbdbdd3f0fbe1fcfefae6febdfce1f4">[email protected]</a>>; Chromestatus <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="dabbbef4f4f49ab9a8f7a9aebbaeafa9f4bbaaaaa9aab5aeb7bbb3b6f4b9b5b7">[email protected]</a>> *Subject:* [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: IDNA ContextJ rules
Thank you Alex and Dan,
What I proposed above is to gradually enable this feature with Finch as a way to mitigate the unknown risk.
However, I realized I could do some httparchive research to gauge the risk. Having done that, I'd now like to instead enable the flag and use Finch only as a kill switch.
Details of what I did:
I looked at all response bodies that match the regular expression "https?://xn--[a-z0-9-.]*/" and extracted all matches. There were 117k sites with matches. Then I decoded all of the hosts in the results, and there were only 59k unique hosts.
Out of those, a single one contained a U+200C or U+200D. That's a link in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://temora.com.au/relocate">https://temora.com.au/relocate</a> with this markup:
<a href="<a rel="nofollow" href="http://xn--https-wt3b//www.temorapodiatry.com.au/">http://xn--https-wt3b//www.temorapodiatry.com.au/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://xn--https-wt3b/www.temorapodiatry.com.au/">http://xn--https-wt3b/www.temorapodiatry.com.au/</a>>">
The "xn--https-wt3b" host there decodes to "\u200dhttps" and obviously it's not a working link or intentional.
To ensure my script wasn't broken I added xn--1ug574b1l58a.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://xn--1ug574b1l58a.com/">http://xn--1ug574b1l58a.com/</a>> (which would be 🐦‍⬛.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://xn--w5i.com/">http://xn--w5i.com/</a>>) to confirm that would've been logged, and it was.
This isn't the widest possible search since it doesn't include Unicode hostnames. It seems like BigQuery doesn't support unicode escapes, so I couldn't search for domains containing U+200C or U+200D directly.
Nevertheless, I think that if there's only a single instance of such a host being encoded as xn-- punycode, then it's not going to be at all common. Together with the fact that the URLs don't work in Firefox or Safari at all, I'd like to ship using a kill switch, plus an enterprise policy just to be safe.
Does that plan sound OK?
On Mon, Sep 29, 2025 at 8:26 PM 'Dan Clark' via blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="e88a84818683c58c8d9ea88b809a8785819d85c6879a8f">[email protected]</a>> wrote:

On Monday, September 29, 2025 at 11:25:35 AM UTC-7 <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="2457484d434c0a0a0a64474c564b494d51490a4b5643">[email protected]</a> wrote:
LGTM1; thanks for doing this so carefully.
On Friday, September 26, 2025 at 12:05:02 PM UTC-7 Chromestatus wrote:
*Contact emails*
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b3d5dcdc9d9d9df3d0dbc1dcdedac6de9ddcc1d4">[email protected]</a>
*Specification*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#idna">https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#idna</a>
*Summary*
IDNA is the mechanism for non-ASCII characters in domain names, encoding a URL like <a rel="nofollow" href="http://네이버.한국/">http://네이버.한국/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://xn--950bt9s8xi.xn--3e0b707e/">http://xn--950bt9s8xi.xn--3e0b707e/</a>> as <a rel="nofollow" href="http://xn--950bt9s8xi.xn--3e0b707e/">http://xn--950bt9s8xi.xn--3e0b707e/</a> (a redirect to naver.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://naver.com/">https://naver.com/</a>>). The processing is defined by <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr46/#Processing">https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr46/#Processing</a> and is invoked by <a rel="nofollow" href="https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#idna">https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#idna</a>. The URL spec sets the CheckJoiners flag, which enables the ContextJ rules in IDNA2008: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5892.html#appendix-A.1">https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5892.html#appendix-A.1</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5892.html#appendix-A.2">https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5892.html#appendix-A.2</a> This disallows ZWNJ (U+200C ZERO WIDTH NON-JOINER) and ZWJ (U+200D ZERO WIDTH JOINER) in most places in URLs. The implementation is to simply pass the UIDNA_CHECK_CONTEXTJ option to ICU, where this rule is implemented:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/icu/source/common/uts46.cpp;l=1137-1204;drc=8a1988938d4298fbe8fb499b1a59fe4b04a21b15">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/icu/source/common/uts46.cpp;l=1137-1204;drc=8a1988938d4298fbe8fb499b1a59fe4b04a21b15</a> This would fix over 200 subtests in WPT relating to IDNA, which already pass in Firefox and Safari:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6990929">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6990929</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/url/IdnaTestV2.window.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/url/IdnaTestV2.window.html</a> All of the IdnaTestV2 cases that would regress from shipping ICU 77 (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5143313833000960">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5143313833000960</a>) would also be fixed again by this change.
*Blink component*
Blink>Network
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%22</a>>
*Web Feature ID*
url <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webstatus.dev/features/url">https://webstatus.dev/features/url</a>>
*Search tags*
idna <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://features#tags:idna">http://features#tags:idna</a>>
*TAG review*
None
*TAG review status*
Not applicable
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility*
Interoperability is improved by bringing URL parsing closer to Firefox and Safari. The web compat risk is most likely very low because the URLs that will be rejected don't work at all in Firefox or Safari. On the other hand, any breakage would be very severe for the same reason. To make this change safely I would suggest a gradual Finch rollout.
/Gecko/: Shipped/Shipping Shipped for a long time, exact version not found
/WebKit/: Shipped/Shipping Shipped for a long time, exact version not found
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:

/Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? /
None

None
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?*
Yes

<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?*
Yes<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/url/IdnaTestV2.window.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/url/IdnaTestV2.window.html</a>

Cannot be measured with use counters because the URL parser is used in many places in Chrome, and not all of them have access to an ExecutionContext or similar. <div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Web+Smart+Card+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Web Smart Card API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Daniel+Clark%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Daniel Clark' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251018" rel="nofollow">Sat, 18 Oct 2025 14:32:01 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>LGTM3 ________________________________ From: Mike Taylor <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="f19c989a948590dfdfdfb19299839e9c98849cdf9e8396">[email protected]</a>> Sent: Monday, October 6, 2025 4:09 PM To: Alex Russell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="80f3ece9e7e8f4ecf9aeaeaec0e3e8f2efede9f5edaeeff2e7">[email protected]</a>>; blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1b7977727570367f7e6d5b7873697476726e763574697c">[email protected]</a>> Cc: Reilly Grant <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5c2e3935307272721c3f342e333135293172332e3b">[email protected]</a>>; Zgroza (Luke) Klimek <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5b213c297575751b3833293436322e367534293c">[email protected]</a>> Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Web Smart Card API</pre><pre>
LGTM2 (thanks for the very well-written explainer, btw).
On 10/6/25 2:19 p.m., Alex Russell wrote: LGTM1
On Thursday, October 2, 2025 at 12:57:05 PM UTC-7 Reilly Grant wrote: LGTM as an IWA OWNER (3x LGTM from Blink API OWNERS are still required according to the IWA-specific API launch process<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/isolated-web-apps/">https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/isolated-web-apps/</a>>).
Similar to Unrestricted WebUSB, this API is granting access to devices which we've made an explicit decision not to give to normal web sites. The additional integrity provided by IWAs allows us to make a meaningful decision that if access is granted to an app then the app's behavior is well-known and cannot be compromised by common attack vectors.
This API exists to support specific, mainly enterprise-focused, use cases. On the broader web device-based authentication solutions such as WebAuthn are more appropriate. Reilly Grant | Software Engineer | <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="a8dacdc1c4868686e8cbc0dac7c5c1ddc586c7dacf">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#c6b4a3afaae8e8e886a5aeb4a9abafb3abe8a9b4a1">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="a5d7c0ccc98b8b8be5c6cdd7cac8ccd0c88bcad7c2">[email protected]</span></a>> | Google Chrome<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.google.com/chrome">https://www.google.com/chrome</a>>
On Thu, Oct 2, 2025 at 6:39 AM Luke Klimek <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0d776a7f2323234d6e657f626064786023627f6a">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#d7adb0a5f9f9f997b4bfa5b8babea2baf9b8a5b0">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="205a47520e0e0e604348524f4d49554d0e4f5247">[email protected]</span></a>>> wrote:
Contact emails
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="760c110458585836151e04191b1f031b58190411">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#1e64796c3030305e7d766c7173776b7330716c79">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="bfc5d8cd919191ffdcd7cdd0d2d6cad291d0cdd8">[email protected]</span></a>>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5236333c3620337c7c7c12353d3d353e377c313d3f">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#781c19161c0a19565656381f17171f141d561b1715">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4e2a2f202a3c2f6060600e29212129222b602d2123">[email protected]</span></a>>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/README.md</a>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card">https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card</a>
Summary
Enables smart card (PC/SC) applications to move to the Web platform. It gives them access to the PC/SC implementation (and card reader drivers) available in the host OS.
Administrators can control the availability of this API either:
* Globally—using the DefaultSmartCardConnectSetting policy. * Per-application—using the SmartCardConnectAllowedForUrls and SmartCardConnectBlockedForUrls policies.
Blink component
Blink>SmartCard<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ESmartCard%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ESmartCard%22</a>>
Web Feature ID
None
TAG review
This is an IWA-only API, and TAG has made it clear recently that they don't want to review IWA-related stuff. Relevant statement: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/842#issuecomment-2917031448">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/842#issuecomment-2917031448</a>
TAG review status
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Other browsers may choose to implement this API, that is however dependent on adoption of the Isolated Web Apps as a whole.
Gecko: No signal
WebKit: No signal
Web developers: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/issues/43">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/issues/43</a>)
Other signals:
Security
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card?tab=readme-ov-file#security-and-privacy-considerations">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card?tab=readme-ov-file#security-and-privacy-considerations</a>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card/#security-privacy">https://wicg.github.io/web-smart-card/#security-privacy</a>
This is a highly security-sensitive API. This is why it is currently being guarded behind:
1. Isolated Web App installation (and also declaration of the `smart-card` permission policy in the manifest
2. Fine-grained user-facing permission mechanism that gives the end user control over the most privacy-sensitive moments (connection to a smart card reader).
For more context on the permissions design and how it interacts with Chrome UI and enterprise policy see go/web-smart-card-api-permissions<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://goto.google.com/web-smart-card-api-permissions">http://goto.google.com/web-smart-card-api-permissions</a>> (sorry, Googlers-only).
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None.
Debuggability
The code using this API can be debugged using the standard tools. Potential future improvement would be a new CDP domain to allow mocking system PC/SC to not rely on actual hardware.
More design explorations at go/web-smart-card-api-cdp<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://goto.google.com/web-smart-card-api-cdp">http://goto.google.com/web-smart-card-api-cdp</a>>, sorry, Googlers-only. Complexity of this endeavour however makes us defer this at least until cross-platform launch. This is a part of a broader effort to add WPTs to this feature: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/40275258">https://crbug.com/40275258</a>
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No. Underlying implementation highly depends on the system native PC/SC stack. ChromeOS is the first platform implemented. Also, IWAs themselves are not currently launched anywhere else.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
No. WPT does not support IWA test environments. Once that support is available, we can investigate adding IWA-focused WPT tests. Also, implementation also is highly complex, as the API depends on communication with the native system PC/SC and actual hardware. Future WPT implementation, tentatively planned for the cross-platform launch is tracked here: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/40275258">https://crbug.com/40275258</a>
DevTrial instructions
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/HOWTO.md">https://github.com/WICG/web-smart-card/blob/main/HOWTO.md</a>
Flag name on about://flags
enable-smart-card-web-api
Finch feature name
SmartCard
Rollout plan
Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome?
True
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1386175">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1386175</a>
Launch bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4234437">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4234437</a>
Measurement
UseCounters:
1. SmartCardEstablishContext: Entry point to the API overall. 2. SmartCardConnect: Entry point to actually using API for communication with smart card readers.
Availability expectation
API is available only in Chromium browsers for the foreseeable future—no other browser engine has yet displayed interest in implementing Isolated Web Apps, which are a prerequisite to this API. Initially API will be available on ChromeOS only, with intent to implement it elsewhere later (as Isolated Web Apps are launched on other platforms).
Adoption expectation
Expected to be used initially by a small number of developers inside Isolated Web Apps.
Adoption plan
Working directly with developers that are planning to rely on the API.
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function?
Yes. This API depends on the system-specific PC/SC implementation, as it is essentially a proxy to it. For the initial launch on ChromeOS, this extension is the sample provider that should be installed in Chrome for the API to function: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/chromeos_smart_card_connector">https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/chromeos_smart_card_connector</a> On the other platforms, we will probably add new dependencies (PCSC on Windows and PC/SC lite elsewhere) to the Chromium project itself.
Sample links
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/web-smartcard-demo">https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/web-smartcard-demo</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop
143
DevTrial on desktop
141
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
None.

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+EditContext%5C%3A+TextFormat+underlineStyle+and+underlineThickness%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: EditContext: TextFormat underlineStyle and underlineThickness</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27ASHISH+KUMAR%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'ASHISH KUMAR' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251018" rel="nofollow">Sat, 18 Oct 2025 16:26:07 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Hi Rick, We are in touch with the impacted major consumers(Google docs and codemirror) and they are aware about these changes. I have responded to your other comment inline.</pre><pre>
Thanks, Ashish
________________________________ From: Rick Byers <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3d4f5f441313137d5e554f525054485013524f5a">[email protected]</a>> Sent: Wednesday, October 15, 2025 9:03 PM To: Vladimir Levin <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6d1b001d4343432d0e051f020004180043021f0a">[email protected]</a>> Cc: blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="dfbdb3b6b1b4f2bbbaa99fbcb7adb0b2b6aab2f1b0adb8">[email protected]</a>>; Chris Harrelson <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="2f4c475d465c0101016f4c475d4042465a4201405d48">[email protected]</a>>; Daniel Clark <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4b2f2a256565650b262228392438242d3f65282426">[email protected]</a>>; Rakesh Goulikar <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="c9bba8a2acbaa1e7aea6bca5a0e7e7e789a4a0aabba6baa6afbde7aaa6a4">[email protected]</a>>; ASHISH KUMAR <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="dcbdafb4b5afb4f2f2f29cb1b5bfaeb3afb3baa8f2bfb3b1">[email protected]</a>> Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: EditContext: TextFormat underlineStyle and underlineThickness

On Wed, Oct 15, 2025 at 11:25 AM Vladimir Levin <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="c0b6adb0eeeeee80a3a8b2afada9b5adeeafb2a7">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#cfb9a2bfe1e1e18faca7bda0a2a6baa2e1a0bda8">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="bec8d3ce909090feddd6ccd1d3d7cbd390d1ccd9">[email protected]</span></a>>> wrote: LGTM2
On Wednesday, October 15, 2025 at 11:19:36 AM UTC-4 Chris Harrelson wrote: LGTM1
On Wed, Oct 15, 2025 at 8:11 AM 'ASHISH KUMAR' via blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="56343a3f383d7b32332016353e24393b3f233b78392431">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#abc9c7c2c5c086cfceddebc8c3d9c4c6c2dec685c4d9cc">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="c7a5abaea9aceaa3a2b187a4afb5a8aaaeb2aae9a8b5a0">[email protected]</span></a>>> wrote:
Hi blink-dev reviewers,
I am working to update the underlineStyle and underlineThickness attributes of TextFormat<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextFormat">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextFormat</a>> object in EditContext as per the spec<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/edit-context/#dom-underlinestyle">https://w3c.github.io/edit-context/#dom-underlinestyle</a>>. Sharing the I2S, please let me know if there are any concerns.
________________________________ Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1776647f7e647f393939577a7e746578647871633974787a">[email protected]</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#e485978c8d978ccacacaa4898d87968b978b8290ca878b89">mailto:<span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="dfbeacb7b6acb7f1f1f19fb2b6bcadb0acb0b9abf1bcb0b2">[email protected]</span></a>>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/edit-context/#textformatupdateevent">https://w3c.github.io/edit-context/#textformatupdateevent</a>
Summary Chromium shipped EditContext<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EditContext">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EditContext</a>> with a bug where the TextFormat<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextFormat">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextFormat</a>> object supplied by the textformatupdate_event<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EditContext/textformatupdate_event">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EditContext/textformatupdate_event</a>> provides incorrect values for the underlineStyle and underlineThickness properties. In Chromium the possible values are {“None”, “Solid”, “Dotted”, “Dashed”, “Squiggle”} and {“None”, “Thin”, “Thick”}, when per spec: EditContext API<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/edit-context/#dom-underlinestyle">https://w3c.github.io/edit-context/#dom-underlinestyle</a>> they should be {“none”, “solid”, “dotted”, “dashed”, “wavy”} and {“none”, “thin”, “thick”}. This Intent covers switching TextFormat.underlineStyle and TextFormat.underlineThickness to use the spec values. This change is valuable because it aligns these attributes with existing CSS text-decoration-style<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-decoration-style">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-decoration-style</a>> and the platform convention that enumeration values are lower-cased<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/design-principles/#casing-rules">https://www.w3.org/TR/design-principles/#casing-rules</a>>. Since the purpose of the TextFormat properties is to be used in applying these text styles to text being composed on behalf of an IME, it will be more convenient for developers if the underlineStyle value can be applied directly from the event to CSS without need for a remapping. For both underlineStyle and underlineThickness, matching the platform lower-case convention will reduce the likelihood of developer confusion.
Blink component Blink>Editing>EditContext<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EEditing%3EEditContext%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EEditing%3EEditContext%22</a>>

entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Extend Experiment: Extended lifetime shared workers
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Extend+Experiment%5C%3A+Extended+lifetime+shared+workers%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Extend Experiment: Extended lifetime shared workers</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251002" rel="nofollow">Thu, 02 Oct 2025 01:10:47 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails dome...@chromium.org, yyanagis...@chromium.org </pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://gist.github.com/domenic/c5bd38339f33b49120ae11b3b4af5b9b#file-1-explainer-md">https://gist.github.com/domenic/c5bd38339f33b49120ae11b3b4af5b9b#file-1-explainer-md</a>
Specification None
Summary This adds a new option, `extendedLifetime: true`, to the `SharedWorker` constructor. This requests that the shared worker be kept alive even after all current clients have unloaded. The primary use case is to allow pages to perform asynchronous work that requires JavaScript after a page unloads, without needing to rely on a service worker.
Blink component Blink>Workers
Web Feature ID shared-workers
TAG review <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1089">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1089</a>
TAG review status Pending
Origin Trial Name Extended lifetime shared workers
Chromium Trial Name SharedWorkerExtendedLifetime
Origin Trial documentation link <a rel="nofollow" href="https://gist.github.com/domenic/c5bd38339f33b49120ae11b3b4af5b9b#file-1-explainer-md">https://gist.github.com/domenic/c5bd38339f33b49120ae11b3b4af5b9b#file-1-explainer-md</a>
WebFeature UseCounter name kSharedWorkerExtendedLifetimeFeatureEnabled
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility We intend to specify that the lifetime timeout for these shared workers be extended in the same way as service workers. Because the exact timeout of service workers is left implementation-defined, it's possible that code using this new feature could be non-interoperable. However, this has so far not proved to be a major problem in practice for service workers.
Gecko: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1227">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1227</a>) Some unofficial tentative positive signals and engagement in the proposal issue.
WebKit: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/492">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/492</a>) Some unofficial tentative negative signals in the proposal issue.
Web developers: Positive The problem of wanting to perform asynchronous work during unload is well-known, with the service worker workaround currently deployed, including by Google properties.
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? None
Goals for experimentation
Reason this experiment is being extended Developer participation in the Origin Trial has increased significantly, with most of the growth occurring since mid-September. As this momentum is recent, an extension is needed to allow developers sufficient time to conduct thorough experiments and to provide us with more comprehensive usage data and insights. To aid developers in their experimentation, we have also improved debuggability. The chrome://inspect/#workers page now indicates when a SharedWorker is using the extendedLifetime option. Separately, the standardization process is progressing well. The corresponding pull request to the WHATWG HTML specification (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11600">https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11600</a>) is under review and has received positive signals, including an LGTM from Mozilla. Extending the trial will allow this real-world testing to continue while the specification solidifies.
Ongoing technical constraints None
Debuggability The chrome://inspect/#workers page indicates when a SharedWorker is using the extendedLifetime option.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? NoShared workers are not yet supported on Android and Android WebView. However, we are concurrently working on enabling them there, and when we do, this feature will also be supported.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/workers/tentative/SharedWorker-extendedLifetime.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/workers/tentative/SharedWorker-extendedLifetime.html</a>
Flag name on about://flags None
Finch feature name SharedWorkerExtendedLifetime
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/400473072">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/400473072</a>
Estimated milestones
Origin trial desktop first 139
Origin trial desktop last 142
Origin trial extension 1 end milestone 145

Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). We are currently discussing some details in preparation for specification. The exact nature of how the lifetime extension works with regard to non-window clients, particularly, has only recently reached a tentative conclusion.
